block.p: Putin Getting Results But Concerns Persist Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has relied on high ratings and an economy buoyed by strong oil prices to begin putting Russia back in order. But the question is whether Russia's democratic institutions are strong enough to resist the authoritarian streak that critics ascribe to Mr. Putin.
AIDS Weakens African Schools In the Ivory Coast and other African countries, large numbers of teachers are dying of AIDS, further weakening educational systems.

Mideast Deadline Nears The White House is prepared to convene a new summit meeting between Palestinians and Israelis, but it has calculated that the effective deadline for a settlement is the end of September.

Allied Airstrikes on Iraq A second day of allied airstrikes over southern Iraq damaged a train station and several homes and wounded at least three people. The United States said allied aircraft hit two Iraqi air defense sites after antiaircraft artillery fired on planes patrolling the no-flight zone.
Indonesia's Noisy Legislature The Indonesian Parliament is meeting without the usual violent protests outside, but with a power struggle inside as the country tries to build democratic institutions.

North Korean Overtures Kim Jong Il, the leader of North Korea, has said he would open ties with the United States right away if it removes his country from a list of nations that are said to sponsor terrorism.
Crackdown in China Police activity has increased in China as the country undergoes a tightening of controls ahead of the Oct. 1 National Day holiday.
Mexico to Seek Open Border Vicente Fox, the winner of Mexico's presidential election, said he would press American officials to open the border to Mexican workers.
Somalis Form a Government More than 2,000 Somalis, meeting in Djibouti, formed a central government after almost a decade of warfare. Somalia has had no central government since 1991.

Delegates Are Liberal Face Of Democrats, Poll Finds Most of the 4,339 delegates at the Democratic National Convention think of themselves as moderates, but their views on issues from affirmative action to an activist federal government are more liberal than those of the public or even Democratic voters generally, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

The Democratic platform, like its Republican counterpart, tries to reach voters in the middle, calling for better schools, stricter border controls, expanded global trade, a stronger military and the death penalty. But the platforms sharply diverge on issues like taxes, Social Security, financing for public schools, gay rights and workers' rights.

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, while seeking to minimize his differences with Vice President Al Gore on some of the leading issues of the campaign, revealed a potentially contentious disagreement in their views about raising the retirement age for Social Security and Medicare. Mr. Lieberman said any debate on keeping the system solvent should consider raising the retirement age.
More than 3,500 protesters marched through Los Angeles on the eve of the Democratic convention, demanding the end of capital punishment and a new trial for Mumia Abu-Jamal, a convicted murderer.

Bush Defends Cheney's Deal Gov. George W. Bush defended the generous retirement deal that Dick Cheney received from his former employer. But Democrats questioned the message it sent to working people, especially since Republicans have resisted increasing the minimum wage.

Reform Party's 2 Nominees The associates of the presidential nominees of a split Reform Party, Patrick J. Buchanan and John Hagelin, plotted legal strategies to seize the $12.6 million in federal campaign money that awaits the true nominee once a court settles the issue.

Life After Welfare Schuyler County was the first county in Illinois to be ''welfare-free'' and one of the nation's first. The end of cash assistance resulted not just from a strong economy, but also from hard work by local welfare officials. Life is not easy for the former welfare recipients, but they say they prefer earning paychecks to welfare.

New Jersey Assesses Toll Of a Persistent Storm Saturday's thunderstorm dropped 14 inches of rain on Jefferson Township in north-central New Jersey. The damage included 300 homes flooded, several bridges and roads washed out, downed trees, ruined cars and boats and two dams gone. No one was killed, but the damage in Jefferson Township and in surrounding Morris, Sussex, Passaic, Bergen, Warren, Essex and Hunterdon Counties may run into hundreds of millions of dollars.

Reclusive Gunman Had Arsenal Arthur Alalouf, the Brooklyn man who wounded four police officers on Saturday before he was killed in a shootout, had lived for years as something of a hermit before he unraveled, the police said. Neighbors said he made them nervous. A search of his home after the police killed him turned up an armory of pistols, rifles and shotguns in his basement and samurai swords in a closet. He also had knives and daggers, the police said, and boxes upon boxes of ammunition.

Worries Over Energy Demands The surging demand for electricity is so intense in New York that at least 13 power plant proposals have been made recently for the city. Blackouts, equipment failures and soaring energy costs have raised awareness about the delicate balance of electricity supply and demand. Air quality, energy reliability and electricity costs are all at stake in a debate that is likely to be influenced by politics and money.

Mets Creep Closer Al Leiter struck out 12 and gave up two hits, and Robin Ventura hit a double in the eighth to lead the Mets over the San Francisco Giants, 2-0. The Mets moved within a game and a half of the first-place Atlanta Braves.
Golfer Ends Title Drought Meg Mallon won the du Maurier Classic in Quebec. It was her first L.P.G.A. major title since 1991.

Early Tire Complaints Revealed Ford released documents showing that by 1997 Bridgestone/Firestone had begun receiving many complaints of injuries and property damage involving Firestone tires that were not recalled until last Wednesday. Many of those claims were sent to Bridgestone by vehicle owners from 1997 to 1999, but the tire maker did not tell Ford, whose new vehicles, particularly the Ford Explorer, are equipped with two-thirds of the recalled tires.

Phone Strike Continues Despite some progress, a quick end to the strike by employees of Verizon, the nation's largest telecommunications employer, appeared unlikely after unions rejected parts of the company's latest proposal.

Competition for Microsoft A group of Linux software developers and computer makers plan to create a foundation to offer a unified desktop user interface and a set of productivity programs intended to compete as a free alternative to Microsoft's Office suite of applications for the personal computer.
Korean Cuts Stake in Auto Firm Hyundai, South Korea's largest business group, said its founder would sell a 6.1 percent stake in the Hyundai Motor Company.
